Award.AwardTitle: Situating Big Data: Assessing Game-Based STEM Learning in Context

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This REAL project arises from the 2013 solicitation on Data-intensive Research to Improve Teaching and Learning. The intention of that effort is to bring together researchers from across disciplines to foster novel, transformative, multidisciplinary approaches to using the data in large education-related data sets to create actionable knowledge for improving STEM teaching and learning environments in the medium term and to revolutionize learning in the longer term. The project team aims to understand how to use data collected from the environment in which learning technologies are used to do the following: (1) allow automated assessment that takes the full range of classroom activities and discussions around use of the technology into account in providing customized feedback recommendations; (2) come to better understand how learning and the context in which it is happening interact; and, (3) provide theory-informed and evidence-based advice for refining learning approaches and activities. This will make it easier for teachers to manage ongoing assessment and to adapt classroom activities to learners' needs in learner-centered, project-based, and inquiry-driven learning environments. Results of this project will lay the foundations for making assessment regular, routine and ongoing and to take a fuller range of learning activities into account. This, in turn, will allow better personalization and ongoing feedback and scaffolding for learners. Results will enhance understanding of how to assess and foster not only disciplinary learning, but also disposition, identity development, and long-term participation.

The PIs seek to integrate theories of situated cognition with analysis of big data. They will explore how to integrate clickstream data from technology with key forms of multimodal data describing the contexts in which the technology is being used, e.g., individual and group discourse (online and in-room), individual and curricular artifacts, classroom assessments, and school performance, to generate a data-driven methodology for: (1) understanding the learning happening in technology-rich learning environments; (2) assessing development and needs of individuals within those environments in ways that will suggest adaptations and scaffolding; and (3) investigating situated cognition. They aim to make it easier to manage ongoing assessment and to adapt classroom activities to learners' needs in learner-centered, project-based, and inquiry-driven learning environments. They will investigate how to (1) enable consideration of the full ecosystem of learning and data collected across it when assessing learning and engagement, and (2) identify what is working and not working to foster learning in a situation. They will demonstrate where and how useful data are situated in the learning ecology when learners are engaged in hands-on and discourse-rich learning activities, and how to use these data to assess effectiveness and impact of interventions. Their plan involves matching important patterns in hand-coded qualitative data to patterns of automatically collected data; this will allow them to identify the patterns in automated data collection that can be used as indicators of factors such as understanding, confusion, learning, and participation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to connect clickstream data to multimodal data in a theoretically principled and empirically validated manner. Specifically, we wanted to bridge the broader forms of data considered central from the theory of situated cognition – data including individual and group discourse (online and in-room), artifact analysis, classroom assessments, and school performance data (grades and test scores) – to data exhaust from learning technologies (here, educational games) in order to create a more authentic account of learning.

By combining our expertise with qualitative analysis of game-based learning, data mining, novel data structuring, and scaled data collection across multiple contexts, we hoped to enable big data analysis in educational research to expand its horizon and cover more of what is verifiably valuable in understanding learning in context. This project, then, studied individual and group learning across a tested science learning game entitled Virulent using diverse datasets, data types, and analyses, including the ADAGE telemetry data architecture? a shared online community forum? and traditional qualitative and quantitative data from the classroom context.

In the first stage of the project, we extended a telemetry data architecture ADAGE to the game Virulent and rebuilt and launched our online community asynchronous environment for peer discussion. In the second stage of the project, we developed a five-day game-based curriculum and collected data across three implementation contexts for a total sample size of 60 students. In our five-day curriculum, participants roleplayed as scientists recruited by the "Center for Disease Control" to stop an international Raven virus epidemic. Students worked in groups or “research teams” using Virulent on iPads as “digiscopes” with the game levels framed as “microscopic slides.”  In the third stage of the project, we extracted and cleaned the data for analysis, digitized and organized all artifacts, segmented and prepared for transcription all audio files. Three teams then conducted analyses simultaneously on the data corpus. One team focused on educational data mining on the telemetry data. A second team focused on qualitatively coding and then quantifying the talk data. A third team focused on applying natural language processing techniques to the talk data.

Several significant findings resulted. Analyses of pre/post assessments show an increase in participants’ content knowledge related to virology and biology (a two grade increase or 22.1%), increases in positive orientation and attitudes toward science, and confidence in their ability to complete science-related tasks. Analyses predicting post assessment scores show level failures before initial success, total attempts at main levels, and pre assessment scores predicted pre/post gains. Using average word length as a proxy for sophistication of talk, we found that group talk increased in sophistication over time and used more biology vocabulary words.In addition, NLP analyses revealed that the number of function words and proportion of keywords explained 16% of the variance in the gain scores for the virology tests. Finally, analysis of scientific argumentation revealed a decrease of declarative (claim) statements and an increase of defense statements over time.

Intellectual Merit

This project has contributed to the disciplines of learning sciences, learning analytics, and games-based education in terms of practical data collection strategies and data analysis methods applied to heterogeneous data sets. This project was ambitious, aiming to automate the collection and analysis of combined telemetry and talk data sets. We have faced significant challenges in so doing as well as moments of partial success that have at least made incremental progress toward our goals to understand (1) How data streams from talk around a device can be integrated into telemetry sets, (2) What forms of analysis this effort might enable, and (3) What new discoveries it might facilitate. As to the first question, the answer is that such streams are not integrated easily and certainly cannot be integrated automatically at this time. Until language recognition software is dramatically improved such that it can handle group talk data (particularly, excited group talk data), we predict relatively little progress in this area. As to the second and third questions, the forms of analysis such work might enable and new discoveries it might facilitate will continue to emerge slowly from this work and similar efforts in the domain. Through this work, we have so far discovered that failure can facilitate learning and that there are shifts in collective talk that seem to predict educational outcomes from these sort of game-based group activities: increasing sophistication over time (word length, vocabulary use), increasing content talk over time (number of function words, proportion of keywords), and  the proportion of declarative versus justification statements. Additional analyses will be slow coming but worth the effort, in our view.

Broader Impacts

The development of such data analytic techniques could benefit students and teachers by enabling assessments using digital devices that are formative and authentic yet still scalable. It can improve our educational media and assessment design.
